text: Efficient way to either create a list, or append to it if one already exists?
I'm going through a whole bunch of tuples with a many-to-many correlation, and I want to make a dictionary where each b of (a,b) has a list of all the a's that correspond to a b.

It seems awkward to test for a list at key b in the dictionary, then look for an a, then append a if it's not already there, every single time through the tuple digesting loop; but I haven't found a better way yet.
Is there some other way to do this that's a lot prettier?
